title: Temporary residents: Countries designated for the purposes of the Visiting Forces Act
manual: Temporary residents: Countries designated for the purposes of the Visiting Forces Act
heading_path: Temporary residents: Countries designated for the purposes of the Visiting Forces Act
text:
Published Time: Wed, 11 Feb 2026 22:01:27 GMT

Temporary residents: Countries designated for the purposes of the Visiting Forces Act
=====================================================================================

This section contains policy, procedures and guidance used by IRCC staff. It is posted on the department’s website as a courtesy to stakeholders.

On this page
------------

* [Military members](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/visitors/countries-designated-purposes-visiting-forces-act.html#military)
* [Civilian personnel](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/visitors/countries-designated-purposes-visiting-forces-act.html#civilian)

Military members
----------------

A foreign national is exempt from the requirement to obtain a temporary resident visa, as per [R190(3)(d)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/sor-2002-227/section-190.html) if:

* they are seeking to enter and remain in Canada solely to carry out official duties as a member of the armed forces of a country that is a designated state for the purposes of the [_Visiting Forces Act (VFA)_](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/V-2), **unless** they have been designated under that Act as a civilian component of those armed forces

**Note:** They are also exempt from the requirement to hold a passport under [R52(2)(e)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/sor-2002-227/section-52.html) and the requirement to obtain:

* an [eTA](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/eta.html) under [IRPR 7.1(3)(f)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/sor-2002-227/section-7.1.html).
* a [work permit](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/foreign-workers/work-without-permit/military.html) under [R186(d)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/sor-2002-227/section-186.html).
* a [study permit](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/study-permits/who-needs-study-permit.html) under [R188(1)(b)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/sor-2002-227/section-188.html)
* a medical examination under [R30(1)(d)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-2002-227/section-30.html).

To demonstrate that they qualify for the exemptions indicated above, military members must provide and carry:

* personal identity card issued by the sending State showing names, date of birth, rank and number (if any), service, and photograph; **and**
* individual or collective movement order, issued by an appropriate agency of the sending State and certifying to the status of the individual or group as a member or members of a force and to the movement ordered; **or**
* Invitation letter or other appropriate documentation issued by Canada’s [Department of National Defence](https://www.canada.ca/en/department-national-defence.html).

Although exempt from the passport requirement, they are required to provide [proof of their status in their country of origin](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/visitors/document-requirements.html#exemption).

**Family members** of military members are **not** exempt from passport, biometric, visa and medical requirements, but are exempt from visa and biometric processing fees as per [R296(2)(b)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-2002-227/section-296.html) and [R315.1(2)(d)(iv)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-2002-227/page-37.html#h-690366).

**Note**: Members of a country’s armed forces who are exempt from requiring a TRV and a passport may choose to request a TRV to facilitate travel to Canada under the VFA. In this case, they are not required to pay visa processing fees or provide [biometric information](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/identity-management/biometrics/exemptions.html#toc12).

Civilian personnel
------------------

* Civilian personnel are **not exempt** from passport, biometric, visa/eTA and medical examination requirements.
* However, personnel who have been **designated** as a civilian component of the visiting force under the VFA, and their family members, are **not** required to pay visa processing and biometric fees as per [R296(2)(b)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-2002-227/section-296.html) and [R315.1(2)(d)(iv)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-2002-227/section-315.1.html).

The following countries are designated states for the purposes of the Visiting Forces Act:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

* [A](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/visitors/countries-designated-purposes-visiting-forces-act.html#a)
* [B](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/visitors/countries-designated-purposes-visiting-forces-act.html#b)
* [C](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/visitors/countries-designated-purposes-visiting-forces-act.html#c)
* [D](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/visitors/countries-designated-purposes-visiting-forces-act.html#d)
* [E](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/visitors/countries-designated-purposes-visiting-forces-act.html#e)
* [F](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/visitors/countries-designated-purposes-visiting-forces-act.html#f)

Footnotes
---------

Footnote 1
Civilian personnel have been designated under the VFA as a civilian component of a visiting force if the personnel are in the employ of that force and are not stateless persons, nationals of any state that is not a designated state, or citizens or residents of Canada.

SOR/2009-14; SOR/93-264; SOR/96-78; SOR/68-258; SOR/99-86; P.C. 1999-21; P.C. 1954-1765; P.C. 1953-927; P.C. 2017-260

sections.text:
Published Time: Wed, 11 Feb 2026 22:01:27 GMT

Temporary residents: Countries designated for the purposes of the Visiting Forces Act
=====================================================================================

This section contains policy, procedures and guidance used by IRCC staff. It is posted on the department’s website as a courtesy to stakeholders.

On this page
------------

* [Military members](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/visitors/countries-designated-purposes-visiting-forces-act.html#military)
* [Civilian personnel](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/visitors/countries-designated-purposes-visiting-forces-act.html#civilian)

Military members
----------------

A foreign national is exempt from the requirement to obtain a temporary resident visa, as per [R190(3)(d)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/sor-2002-227/section-190.html) if:

* they are seeking to enter and remain in Canada solely to carry out official duties as a member of the armed forces of a country that is a designated state for the purposes of the [_Visiting Forces Act (VFA)_](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/V-2), **unless** they have been designated under that Act as a civilian component of those armed forces

**Note:** They are also exempt from the requirement to hold a passport under [R52(2)(e)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/sor-2002-227/section-52.html) and the requirement to obtain:

* an [eTA](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/eta.html) under [IRPR 7.1(3)(f)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/sor-2002-227/section-7.1.html).
* a [work permit](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/foreign-workers/work-without-permit/military.html) under [R186(d)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/sor-2002-227/section-186.html).
* a [study permit](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/study-permits/who-needs-study-permit.html) under [R188(1)(b)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/sor-2002-227/section-188.html)
* a medical examination under [R30(1)(d)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-2002-227/section-30.html).

To demonstrate that they qualify for the exemptions indicated above, military members must provide and carry:

* personal identity card issued by the sending State showing names, date of birth, rank and number (if any), service, and photograph; **and**
* individual or collective movement order, issued by an appropriate agency of the sending State and certifying to the status of the individual or group as a member or members of a force and to the movement ordered; **or**
* Invitation letter or other appropriate documentation issued by Canada’s [Department of National Defence](https://www.canada.ca/en/department-national-defence.html).

Although exempt from the passport requirement, they are required to provide [proof of their status in their country of origin](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/temporary-residents/visitors/document-requirements.html#exemption).

**Family members** of military members are **not** exempt from passport, biometric, visa and medical requirements, but are exempt from visa and biometric processing fees as per [R296(2)(b)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-2002-227/section-296.html) and [R315.1(2)(d)(iv)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-2002-227/page-37.html#h-690366).

**Note**: Members of a country’s armed forces who are exempt from requiring a TRV and a passport may choose to request a TRV to facilitate travel to Canada under the VFA. In this case, they are not required to pay visa processing fees or provide [biometric information](https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/corporate/publications-manuals/operational-bulletins-manuals/identity-management/biometrics/exemptions.html#toc12).

Civilian personnel
------------------

* Civilian personnel are **not exempt** from passport, biometric, visa/eTA and medical examination requirements.
* However, personnel who have been **designated** as a civilian component of the visiting force under the VFA, and their family members, are **not** required to pay visa processing and biometric fees as per [R296(2)(b)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-2002-227/section-296.html) and [R315.1(2)(d)(iv)](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-2002-227/section-315.1.html).

Footnotes
---------

Footnote 1
Civilian personnel have been designated under the VFA as a civilian component of a visiting force if the personnel are in the employ of that force and are not stateless persons, nationals of any state that is not a designated state, or citizens or residents of Canada.
